titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Dorothy Richardson Collection
titlestmt.author: by Beinecke Staff

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Friday December 7, 2018 at 04:28
profiledesc.descrules: translation missing: en.enumerations.resource_finding_aid_description_rules.beinecke manuscript unit archival processing manual

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: Correspondence by, to, and about Dorothy Richardson, with manuscripts of her short stories, articles and novels, as well as other writings about Richardson. Accompanied by clippings of articles by and about Richardson and her friends, legal agreements, and photographs. Principal correspondents include John and Ruby Austen, Bernice Elliott, Peggy Kirkaldy, Alan and Rose Odle, Phyllis Playter and John Cowper Powys, Henry Savage, and H. G. Wells.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The Dorothy Richardson Collection was established in 1958 by the gift of letters, manuscripts, annotated books and photographs from her sister-in-law, Mrs. Rose Odle. Additional gifts have been made by Mrs. John Austen, Bryher, Bernice Elliott, John Cowper Powys, Mrs. Harold Tomkinson, and others.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Dorothy Richardson Collection is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Dorothy Richardson Collection. General Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: Many materials have been microfilmed. Consult the Public Service Desk for further information.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: About this Finding Aid: This finding aid, created before the advent of computer-generated files has been converted into a ASCII data file by means of scanning and Optical Character Recognition software. While attempts have been made to retain the complete information from the original document a number of format changes have been made to present the structure of this archive in accordance with current practice.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection is divided into three series:
Letters by others, mostly about Dorothy Richardson
MSS and typescripts of Dorothy Richardson's works
MSS and typescripts of works about Dorothy Richardson
Clippings of articles by Dorothy Richardson
Clippings about other people connected with Dorothy Richardson

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letters by Dorothy Richardson are arranged alphabetically by recipient. Letters to Dorothy Richardson are arranged alphabetically by author. Letters by others, mostly about Dorothy Richardson are arranged alphabetically by author, then by recipient.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contents: Miscellaneous, arranged alphabetically by the first word of the entry assigned; Manuscripts and typescripts of Dorothy Richardson's works; Short stories and articles, arranged by title; Novels, arranged by title; Manuscripts and typescripts of works about Dorothy Richardson, arranged alphabetically by author. The first group, 'Miscellaneous', contains items belonging to Dorothy Richardson such as notebooks, notecards, and an excerpt from a novel by H. G. Wells, which do not fit neatly into any specific category. In describing Dorothy Richardson's shorter works, an attempt has been made to distinguish among short stories, literary essays, and book reviews: the purely fictional works are merely listed with no comment; essays usually have a brief description of their subject matter, except in such instances where the subject is fairly clear from the title; and book reviews list the author and title of the book(s) being reviewed. In instances where it is known, publication information is given. In some cases it was clear from clippings in Series III that a particular article was published in the Saturday Review, but it was impossible to ascertain the volume, number, or date of publication.

did.unittitle: Address books: 2 small notebooks, one containing addresses up to 1945, the other with addresses from 1945 onwards.
Appointment card for Dorothy Richardson at St. Mary's Church, Putney [1889] with much later note by Dorothy Richardson (on verso) about an exhibition of Alan Odle's drawings.
Notebook containing lists of Dorothy Richardson's correspondents, corrections of Pilgrimage , and miscellaneous notes.
Notecards: autograph MS outlines of Dorothy Richardson's schedule of publication for the years 1913, 1914, and 1915. 3 cards.
POEMS & FRAGMENTS: autograph MS list of her poems, written on the back of a postcard.
Wells, Herbert George THE HISTORY OF MR. POLLY: typescript (extract from the first chapter) 1 p. On verso: "Wells" in Dorothy Richardson's hand.
MSS & TYPESCRIPTS OF RICHARDSON'S SHORT STORIES AND ARTICLES
ABOUT PUNCTUATION: typescript (2 carbon copies) 9, 9 p.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contents: Clippings of articles by Dorothy Richardson, arranged alphabetically by title; publication information is provided when known; Clippings about Dorothy Richardson, arranged chronologically; Clippings about Dorothy Richardson's works, arranged alphabetically by title of work, then chronologically within each folder; Clippings about other people connected with Dorothy Richardson, arranged alphabetically by name of person; Legal agreements, arranged alphabetically by name(s) of contractor(s); Photographs, arranged loosely according to subject matter.
